They had such things as mechanisms that could make a statue or a throne rise up. Hero invented a steam driven toy tgat coild turn a spindle. They were very good at shaping and smoothing stone. The Greeks even appear to have had a device that would mimic tge changing positions of planets and stars through cleverly proportioned gear wheels. However, these were little better than mechanical toys. Their ideas had little real world applivpcation. Much has been nade of tge discivery of ‘batteries’ in Ancient Mesopotamia, but again the ancients showed no inkling of appreciating how electricity worked and did bot use it to power anything. The start point of modern technologyvwas to replace labour with machines powered by steam, petrol and electric engines. This replacement of labour was not sought in Ancient times when slaves were cheap and peopke had a lot of available time.

Answer: Digital cameras are very high technology devices.As an example, consider the ESP32-CAM shown above next to a quarter. I bought this particular one new for $6.This is a stand-alone camera module designed to be used in internet-of-things camera applications. The camera it contains is the OV2640, which uses a 2MP color CMOS sensor — and the first CMOS image sensor was created by Eric Fossum in 1995. Of course, digital cameras are computers, and the ESP32 includes a dual-core 32-bit processor, several MB of RAM, support for microSD mass storage, and other facilities that compete favorably with desDigital cameras are very high technology devices.As an example, consider the ESP32-CAM shown above next to a quarter. I bought this particular one new for $6.This is a stand-alone camera module designed to be used in internet-of-things camera applications. The camera it contains is the OV2640, which uses a 2MP color CMOS sensor — and the first CMOS image sensor was created by Eric Fossum in 1995. Of course, digital cameras are computers, and the ESP32 includes a dual-core 32-bit processor, several MB of RAM, support for microSD mass storage, and other facilities that compete favorably with desktop PCs from 20–25 years ago and would have classed as a supercomputer in the 1980s. The camera also includes software that recognizes and identifies faces of individuals you tell it to learn, and that level of machine learning wasn’t a robust technology until the last couple of decades. It also includes wifi and Bluetooth wireless networking, and the basic principles of spread spectrum communication used by both are less than a century old. Even the little high-brightness white LED (the yellow circle in the lower right corner) is technology that simply didn’t exist until the last couple of decades.I know you’re thinking that’s all just about the electronics, and that is largely true. The last 100 years have been dominated by advances in electrical and computer engineering. However, even the tiny lens assembly is a marvel of precision manufacturing and the plastics used for the camera housing and connector shells, and the material used to make the circuit board, are things that didn’t exist a century ago.So, although the basic concept of a camera is millennia old, and lenses and photochemical processes are not particularly recent inventions, a device like the ESP32-CAM would have been nearly unimaginable science fiction a century ago. In fact, the ESP32-CAM isn’t normally used to take photographs, but as an intelligent controller that can make things happen based on what it sees….

However, it is not the only way in which to pursue photography.

This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falsely believes nuclear energy to be more dangerous than fossil fuels due to decades of propaganda by idiots.So no. Germany is not the most technologically advanced country. Answer: Funny you should ask. I’m blind and my hubby is deaf. I can sign to him and he can speak to me. He is also impressive at lip reading for those days when I feel lazy. My computer reads the text to me in a fabulous male British voice called Oliver.

Answer: I’m blind, and my husband is deaf. This is how we communicate:I sign to him, and he talks to me. We also love hanging out with his deaf friends, all who talk to me while I sign to them. The relationship is symbiotic.Those who have never learned to speak, sign to my husband, who then translates to me. No technology involved, just cooperation.There are also deaf/blind folks who do sign language in each other’s hands. I have not mastered that technique, but my husband speaks very well, so I have not had to.Many of the deaf people I have encountered can speak well enough to understand.
